THEIR APPLICATION AS CATALYSTS FOR DIHYDROGEN EVOLUTION E. R. SAVINOVA, E. N. SAVINOV and V. N. PARMON Institute of Catalysis, Novosibirsk 630090 (U.S.S.R.) (Received September 10,1987; accepted March 10,1988) Summary The kinetics of catalytic dihydrogen evolution from acidic aqueous solutions of strong one-electron reductants Vaq24" and the cation radical of methylviologen (MV"1") in the presence of polymer-stabilized copper colloids was studied. This process could be described quantitatively in the framework of an electrochemical 'microelectrode' model. The standard heterogeneous rate constant of proton reduction on finely dispersed copper was determined, its value being found to drop sharply when the size of copper particles decreases from 150 to 25 A. The possibility of applying other non-noble metals, e.g. cobalt, as H; evolution catalysts is discussed. Introduction Numerous studies of the catalytic dihydrogen evolution on colloids of noble metals in the presence of strong one-electron reductants A~ via the reaction: . colloid A- + H-*- > A + Y2H2 (A) carried out in the past 10-15 years have shown that in this process the colloids behave like bulk electrodes at the cathodic evolution of H;. For this reason colloidal particles were called microelectrodes. Two electrochemical reactions are assumed to occur simultaneously on the surface of microelectrodes: A" ?=^ A + es H* + e, ;=^ Y2H2 (1) (2) McLendon et al. have suggested the so-called 'microelectrode' model [1, 2] that describes the process (A) in terms of electrochemical kinetics based on the concept of a mixed potential. 0304-5102/88/$3.60 Elsevier Sequoia/Printed in The Netherlands 232 In this work, experimental results that confirm and specify postulates of the 'microelectrode' model are reported. Also, data on the process of dihydrogen evolution on copper colloids, the influence of the particle size of such colloids on their catalytic activity, as well as the possibility of applying other non-noble metals as H; evolution catalysts are considered. Results and discussion Analysis of the 'microelectrode' model of dihydrogen evolution on metals The 'microelectrode' model in the form developed by McLendon can- not be applied to the quantitative description of the catalytic dihydrogen evolution for a broad class of metals and reductants, since it takes into account only a single particular situation where the rate-determining step of H; evolution is the reaction of proton discharge on the metal, and the step of A~ oxidation is described by a reversible current-voltage curve for this metal. Meanwhile, the mechanism of cathodic H; evolution is known to depend upon the nature of the metal, the rate-determining step being either proton discharge (Volmer mechanism), or electrochemical desorption of hydrogen atoms (Heyrovsky mechanism) or recombination of hydrogen atoms on the metal suface (Tafel mechanism). In the two former cases, the dependence of reaction rate on the electrode potential is the same at a con- stant surface coverage with adsorbed hydrogen atoms. In all equations that 235 Fig. 1. This fall is most likely caused by the protonation of the radical cation of methylviologen, resulting in its electrochemically inert form which is not able to promote reduction of water to Hz [10]. The experimental dependence of v on pH for V2"*" and MV"1" provides evidence that the oxidation of these reductants on copper colloidal particles is reversible, and the catalytic evolution of Hz occurs via case II or IV (Table 2). This seems to be due to the fact that the interaction of copper colloid particles with molecules of the polymer PVPR has little effect on the value of fei , and the surface coverage of hydrogen atoms on finely dispersed copper is low, as on bulk copper [II], especially in the initial time period. Thus, we may conclude that the increase in pHi/2 observed by us with increasing (dg) is, most probably, due to the increase in k^0. The estimate made by eqn. For example, the exchange current density i'o of dihydrogen evolution on bulk copper is 4 X 10~8 A cm~2 [11]. From this value of i'o, using eqn. Probably such a low literature value of k^ is due to the fact that the oxide film usually present on the surface of copper electrodes is not always perfectly removed (see e.g. [15]). In the present work, with copper microelectrodes being obtained in a reducing medium in an inert gas atmosphere, their surface could be expected to be less contaminated by oxygen. Consequently, such particles are more active catalysts for water reduction to Ha than are smaller particles. On the other hand, the maximum achievable rate of the catalytic process, which is observed in strongly acidic solutions and determined by the diffusion of the particles of the reductant to the microelectrodes, is proportional to the total surface area of colloidal particles. Since this area, in the case of con- stant concentration of the colloid-forming metal, decreases with increasing particle size, in order to prepare the catalysts with the highest specific activ- ity (that is, to ensure the highest rate of the catalytic process at a given con- centration of the colloid-forming metal), one should take into account that there exists an optimum for the size of colloidal particles which depends upon the pH. For copper colloids in the case of Ha evolution from solutions of V2'1" with pH 2, this optimum is ca. 50 A. Numerous studies published in recent years indicate that structural and electronic properties of small metal particles can essentially differ from those of bulk metal particles (see e.g. [16], [17] and refs. therein). According to our selected area electron diffraction data, all of the copper colloid particles, small and large, have a crystalline structure analogous to that of bulk copper [3]. In this connection one can assume that a sharp drop in the heteroge- neous rate constant of the proton reduction with particle size of copper colloids decreasing below 150 A is associated with changes in their electronic properties. On the other hand, one cannot exclude that the catalytic properties of copper colloidal particles (especially small ones) in H; formation may be significantly affected by non-stoichiometric oxides present on their surfaces [18]. In fact, we found in [3] that decreasing the size of the copper particles enhances their capability of being completely oxidized (up to Cu2*) by water. Therefore, one should anticipate a similar behavior of copper colloidal par- ticles with respect to formation of surface oxides. In this case, the decrease 245 in fe;0 with decreasing size of copper colloids could be associated with an ever-increasing oxidation of their surfaces by water molecules (the volume of the copper particles being unchanged according to the diffraction data). Thus, the dependence of log k^ on l/<ds) can easily be understood: the higher the ratio of particle surface to particle volume the lower fe;0. Possibility of applying other non-noble metals for the catalytic H^ evolution from water Colloids of some other non-noble metals exhibit essentially the same behavior with respect to water reduction to H; as do copper colloids. For example, Fig. 7 illustrates a typical kinetic curve for dihydrogen evolution during water reduction with V2"*" on the colloid obtained by reduction of CoCI^ solution with NaBH4 in the presence of polyvinylalcohol. One can see that the amount of dihydrogen evolved equals ca. 40% of the amount expected from the stoichiometry of reaction (A), and exceeds by a factor of 10 the amount of cobalt introduced into the system. Consequently, in this case H; is, indeed, formed as a result of the catalytic reaction (A), rather than dissolution of cobalt in acidic aqueous solution. The fact that the reac- tion stops after incomplete conversion of V2"*" to V3"1' is probably due to the oxidation of the catalyst by protons (pH of the solution 1.35) during the course of the reaction. The activity of cobalt colloids tends to fall with time, probably due to a gradual oxidation of the colloid. To study the chemical nature of the cobalt catalyst, we prepared a special sample via reduction of CoCL; solution with NaBH4 in the absence of stabilizer. The black precipitate produced could easily be dissolved in 0.1 N HC1 with gas evolution, Co24" formation and was magnetized by a magnetic field. The sample was found to be X-ray amorphous and had the chemical composition 2.38. Small particles of the Co colloid (d ~ 10 - 20 A) were registered with the help of the electron microscope. However, we did not succeed in obtain- 10 20 30 W 50 t, mhi Fig. 7. Thus, the data obtained do not allow us to define unambiguously the chemical nature of the cobalt catalyst. However, according to the literature data, [19] and refs. therein, the product obtained by the reduction of Co2'1' with BH4~ is most probably a mixture of elemental Co(0) and B(0). Thus, a class of currently available catalysts for water reduction to H; can be significantly broadened via colloids of non-noble metals. Some ex- pected difficulties in the application of non-noble metals such as cobalt seem to be associated with the facts that: (i) due to a low (in comparison with noble metals) heterogeneous rate con- stant of proton reduction, k^ , a high (close to diffusion controlled) reaction rate can be achieved only in strongly acidic media, and (ii) at low pHs most non-noble metals, especially in the finely dispersed state, will be dissolved due to oxidation by protons. Indeed, this latter undesirable phenomenon can be avoided by using stronger reductants, which shift the pHi/; towards a more alkaline region. For example, application of reductants with the standard electrochemical potential 0.8 V, i.e. 0.36 V lower than the standard potential of MV'1", increases the pH;/; by ca. 3 units. In addition, a sufficiently strong reductant should be able to reduce the metal cations formed during metal dissolution to the zero-valent state, and thus to prevent the catalyst from inactivation via dissolution. Conclusions An analysis of the electrochemical 'microelectrode' model of the cata- lytic evolution of dihydrogen on finely dispersed metals has shown that the shape of the dependence of the reaction rate on pH, namely, its position on the pH axis and its slope, as well as the dependence of the rate on the stan- dard reductant electrochemical potential, are important criteria for determi- nation of the mechanism of the catalytic reduction of water to dihydrogen with one-electron reductants. The peculiarities of this process on copper colloids in the presence of V2'1" and MV'1" have been studied. The process can be described quantitatively in the framework of an electrochemical 'micro- electrode' model for the situation, where the rate-determining step of dihy- drogen evolution is the proton discharge, and the current-voltage curve for the reductant oxidation is reversible. The standard heterogeneous rate con- stant for proton reduction on finely dispersed copper has been determined, its value being found to drop when the size of copper particles-microelec- trodes decreases from 150 to 25 A. A rather active colloid catalyst for the reaction of dihydrogen evolution from water has been obtained on the basis of cobalt. This confirms the possible use of various non-noble metals as catalysts for the process under consideration. 247 Acknowledgement The authors are grateful to R. Yu. Beck and V. D.
